importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The date when the article was updated, indicating the current status of Coca-Cola's cane sugar soda rollout in the U.S.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The timeline of the soda's launch and rollout following Trump's earlier endorsement, placing it within the current political and consumer health discourse.

keyTakeAways: Coca-Cola has begun selling a soda made with cane sugar instead of high-fructose corn syrup in select U.S. cities and retailers.
This change follows a public demand from President Donald Trump, who earlier this year stated that Coca-Cola had agreed to use cane sugar.
The move aligns with the advocacy of Health and Human Services Secretary Robert F. Kennedy, Jr., who has criticized high-fructose corn syrup.
While cane sugar is used in some international versions of Coca-Cola (e.g., Mexico), it is not standard in most U.S. products.
Coca-Cola already uses cane sugar in other U.S. beverages such as Simply Lemonade, Gold Peak Iced Tea, and Costa Canned Coffee.
Health experts have noted that sugary sodas—whether made with cane sugar or corn syrup—are not healthy.
The rollout comes alongside Coca-Cola's broader success in healthier drink options, including the growth of Coca-Cola Zero Sugar (up 14% globally) and the relaunch of BodyArmor and Smartwater.
Coca-Cola Zero Sugar saw a 14% global volume growth in Q3 2025, prompting a 3% jump in company shares during early trading.

namedEntities.name: Coca-Cola
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Coca-Cola is the central entity in the article, as it is the company implementing the shift from high-fructose corn syrup to cane sugar in its U.S. soda line following political pressure and public health advocacy.

namedEntities.name: Donald Trump
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Former President of the United States
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Trump initiated public pressure on Coca-Cola to switch to cane sugar, making him a key political figure whose influence prompted the change.

namedEntities.name: Robert F. Kennedy, Jr.
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: U.S. Health and Human Services Secretary
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: He has publicly advocated against high-fructose corn syrup, influencing the public discourse around the soda ingredient switch.

namedEntities.name: High-fructose corn syrup
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A common sweetener in U.S. processed foods and beverages
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: This ingredient was the target of criticism by Trump and Kennedy, and its replacement with cane sugar is the central health and policy issue in the article.

namedEntities.name: Cane sugar
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A natural sweetener derived from sugarcane
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: It is now being used in Coca-Cola’s U.S. soda, marking a shift in ingredient sourcing due to political and health-related pressures.

namedEntities.name: Coca-Cola Zero Sugar
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A sugar-free soda product line by Coca-Cola
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The article highlights its 14% global volume growth and 3% share increase, showing Coca-Cola’s broader shift toward healthier beverage offerings.

namedEntities.name: BodyArmor
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A sports drink brand relaunched by Coca-Cola
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: It is cited as part of Coca-Cola’s successful expansion into healthier, non-sugary drink options.

namedEntities.name: Smartwater
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A bottled water brand by Coca-Cola
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: It is mentioned as part of Coca-Cola’s strategic push toward healthier, alternative beverage products.

namedEntities.name: Simply Lemonade
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Coca-Cola already uses cane sugar in this product, showing the company’s existing use of cane sugar in select U.S. offerings.

namedEntities.name: Gold Peak Iced Tea
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: An iced tea product by Coca-Cola
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Coca-Cola already uses cane sugar in this product, indicating the company’s broader adoption of cane sugar in certain beverages.

namedEntities.name: Costa Canned Coffee
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A canned coffee product by Coca-Cola
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Coca-Cola already uses cane sugar in this product, reinforcing the company’s use of cane sugar in select product lines.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Coca-Cola has begun rolling out a new soda version in select U.S. cities that uses cane sugar instead of high-fructose corn syrup, following a public endorsement from President Donald Trump and advocacy from Health and Human Services Secretary Robert F. Kennedy, Jr. This shift is part of a broader trend toward healthier beverage options, including the success of sugar-free products like Coca-Cola Zero Sugar, which saw a 14% global volume growth and a 3% share increase. Although cane sugar is already used in some Coca-Cola products such as Simply Lemonade, Gold Peak Iced Tea, and Costa Canned Coffee, this new soda marks a significant policy-driven change in the U.S. market, reflecting both political influence and evolving consumer health concerns.
title: Coca-Cola’s Trump-approved soda begins to roll out in the United States
